title: crystal - Wiktionary, the free dictionary
cleaned_text: crystal [Jump to navigation](#mw-head) arranged in pattern which is [periodic](/wiki/periodic)in three dimensions. - ( [countable](/wiki/Appendix:Glossary#countable)) A [mineral](/wiki/mineral)resembling ( [uncountable](/wiki/Appendix:Glossary#uncountable)) A fine type of [glassware](/wiki/glassware), or the material used to make it. - [Slouching Towards Bethlehem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slouching_Towards_Bethlehem): - He tells me he's been shooting crystal, which I already pretty much know because he does not bother to keep his sleeves rolled down over the needle tracks. - ( [obsolete](/wiki/Appendix:Glossary#obsolete), usually in the Shakespeare](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Shakespeare), " of Henry the Fift](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_V_(play))", in Mr. William Shakespeares 2: let's away. My loue, giue me thy Lippes: Looke to they Chrytalls. [Yokefellowes](/wiki/yokefellow#English)in Armes, let vs to France - Come, let's away. My love, kiss me. Look after my goods and property [...] Go, dry your eyes. Comrades in arms, let us to France - The [glass](/wiki/glass)over the | mineral | | glassware | | (used attributively) | | - The translations below need to be checked and inserted above into the appropriate translation tables. See instructions at [Wiktionary:Entry layout § Translations](/wiki/Wiktionary:Entry_layout#Translations). Translations to be checked | | Adjective[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=crystal&action=edit§ion=9)] crystal (not [comparable](/wiki/Appendix:Glossary#comparable)) - Made of crystal. - 1887, Joseph W[arren] Smith, Gleanings from the Sea: Showing the Pleasures, Pains and Penalties of Life Afloat, with Contingencies Ashore, Andover, Mass.: [...] the Author, page 116: - Its ceiling was crystal, around on the wall / Thickly studded were rubies and diamonds rare; / But purer than crystal, and brighter than all / Of the jewels adorning her glittering hall, / Was the mermaiden languishing there. - 1985, [Patricia C[ollins] Wrede](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Patricia_Wrede), [ISBN](/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-441-79591-9), [page 146](https://archive.org/details/talkingtodragons0000wred/page/146/mode/1up): - The walls were crystal, and they seemed to have hundreds of different-colored lights shifting behind them. - 2000, [Dennis L[ester] McKiernan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dennis_L._McKiernan), Silver Wolf, Black Falcon, [Roc Books](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roc_Books), [ISBN](/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-451-45786-2), page 439: - The uneven floor was crystal as well, as if there once had been huge crystals jutting up here, too, but ones that had been broken away and the surface crudely adzed. - - Very clear. - 1595 December 9 (first known performance), [William Shakespeare](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Shakespeare), " [The life and death of King Richard the Second](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_II_(play))", in Mr. William Shakespeares Comedies, Histories, & Tragedies: Published According to Thou art a Traitor, and a Micreant; Too good to be o, and too bad to liue, Since the more faire and chritall is the skie, The vglier eeme the cloudes that in it terms derived from Middle English](/wiki/Category:English_terms_derived_from_Middle_English) [English terms inherited from Old English](/wiki/Category:English_terms_inherited_from_Old_English) [English terms derived from Old English](/wiki/Category:English_terms_derived_from_Old_English) [English terms derived from Latin](/wiki/Category:English_terms_derived_from_Latin) [English terms derived
